- Hello, this is Chef John from foodwishes.com
with double chicken tea.

That's right, all this time you've been drinking
tea made of dried twigs and leaves, while

you could have been drinking a tea made out
of bones and meat, which is exactly what I'm
going to show you how to do here.

And by the way, to be clear, I'm not inventing
anything here.

I'm just rebranding something that's been
around forever.

And all this is is a very concentrated version
of what our parents would have called chicken
bouillon.

But anyway, no matter what you call it, is
an incredible thing to drink.

And to get started, we're going to need two
very large chickens.

These things were weighing in at about four
and a half to five pounds each.

And to achieve maximum flavor and richness,
we're going to use the entire chicken except
for the breast meat.

So before these go into the pot, we'll go
ahead and slice those off the carcass by cutting

down on either side of the breast bone, and
then just sliding our knife blade down across

the ribcage until we get down to that wing
joint, at which point we can just finish hacking
it off.

And this works out great because those breasts
aren't going to add a ton of flavor to the
tea.

And now we can save those for a whole other
meal.

And be sure to reserve all the skin because
that's going in the pot, too.

And then what we'll do once that breast meat
has been removed is transfer our chickens

into either one huge pot or two regular large
stock pots And as you can see, mine are slightly
different size, but that's fine.

eventually all the broth is going to end up
in one pot to reduce anyway.

And then besides our chicken, we will also
add in some Iroquois which is just a fancy

French culinary word for carrots, celery,
and onions.

I'm also going to add exactly two cloves of
garlic to each pot that I did not peel, but
cut in half.
And then we'll also add some bay leaf.

one.

And then we will finish up with just a few
whole black peppercorns.
Right, just like five or six in each pot.
And believe it or not, that's it.

Okay, what we're not putting in here is just
as important as what we are.

So other than these few aromatics, this is
gonna be like 100% chicken.

And then what we'll do is fill these all the
way to the top with some nice cold fresh water,
and we will place those over medium-high heat.

And other than maybe poking a bay leaf down,
all we're gonna do here is hang out, waiting

for this to come up to a boil, which is gonna
take a little while, but don't go anywhere.
And there's a couple great reasons for that.

Okay first of all if you're not around, it
will boil over and totally mess up your stove
and I will get blamed.

But just as importantly, to make a beautifully
clear world-class broth or stock we do not
want to allow this to boil.

So we need to be right here when it starts
to boil so we can back our heat down to low,

or to the heat setting that gives us the perfect,

is gonna take us a while to dial in.

And then the other thing we'll do while all
this flame adjusting's going on is go ahead

and skim any of that white chunky looking
foam off the top with a spoon.

And a lot of people describe that stuff as
impurities, but that's not really the case.
I'm pretty sure that's just protein.

And it really doesn't affect the flavor, but
if you don't skim it off, it can dissolve
